Also in Bolivia, thousands of people gathered
in many squares together to chew
Coca leaves, a long-standing custom of a
forbidden plant with deep roots in indigenous culture.
But it is related to the production of
cocaine. This country's government is actively
working hard to reshape global awareness
of the
Coca leaf. The main event took place in the capital
Lapas last Thursday in the
presence of President Luis AR. Mr. AR
launched an international campaign to eliminate this plant.
Considered an illegal substance,
Coca leaves will no longer be classified as a drug or
something evil. We now
know the benefits and uses of
this leaf. The day we chew Coca leaves or the day aquilo

many products from these leaves. Indigenous people

since 1961 Coca leaves, the raw material for

2013 Bolivia allowed chewing

its territory even though this South American country
had joined  International conventions and

United Nations, Bolivia is the
third largest producer of cocaine in the world, after
Columbia and
